Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: SECURE: Secure Teacher Education on Cybersecurity by Utilizing Research Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award establishes a new Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site focused on cybersecurity research at Texas A&M University. Cohorts of high school teachers and community college faculty in the areas of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) will participate in summer research projects with Texas A&M faculty mentors who are actively involved in leading-edge research on cybersecurity. The participating teachers will translate their research experiences and knowledge into classroom practice by developing instructional modules and course materials that they will introduce in their classrooms and share with others. These activities all contribute to the formation of a community of practice between Texas A&M faculty and local educators that has the potential to significantly enhance and improve STEM education in the school districts around the university.

RET participants will attend a 6-week summer institute to participate in cutting-edge research projects with mentoring from computer science faculty who lead cybersecurity research programs. The RET Site research topics focus on software, network security, cryptography, and malware. These are all topics that are of current interest and important to our nation. The RET Site project will provide a platform for the participating teachers to develop effect practical problem-based instructional materials and laboratory modules that they will share with teachers in their school districts as well as teachers from across the state of Texas. The excitement of learning about cybersecurity can inspire the K-12 and community college students to pursue further computing education and related careers. The SECURE program will strengthen ongoing partnerships between Texas A&M University and the surrounding schools and lay the foundation for quality computing education in the schools and provide for the future computing workforce needs of the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Texas A&M Engineering Experiment Station and Texas A&M University College of Engineering were awarded a Research Experience for Teachers Site #1711919 from 2017-2019. The focus of the project was to Secure teacher Education on Cybersecurity by Utilizing Research Experiences (SECURE). The SECURE program provided opportunities to gain new knowledge and insights about scientific and engineering practices in cybersecurity for teachers of mathematics, computer science, and career technical education in local community college and secondary education settings. The teachers were able to make connections and collaborate with multiple research faculty who work within and across research teams. Teachers learned that research and discovery are rarely done in a vacuum similar to a self-contained classroom and were then able to translate pedagogical approaches and content across their curriculum, their school, and their district to encourage collaboration with distributed expertise, mirroring the research model.

Each participant first successfully completed a cyber-basics course provided by Texas A&M Engineering Extension Service which could also be deployed later to their students. Then cyber security topics were taught such as software, network security, cryptography, and malware. Faculty from the College of Education worked with the teachers daily on curriculum mapping to help them connect to the state standards and successfully roadmap their project.

Over three years, the project built a professional learning community consisting of 30 local teachers, 37 faculty and graduate students, 18 local business representatives and the Spark! PK-12 Engineering Education Outreach team and their statewide network. This professional learning community was created to help stakeholders vertically align their project and cybersecurity essentials from middle school to higher education to career opportunities. All teachers were invited to the campus with their students and project personnel visited each classroom at least twice to critique their progress. All teachers were invited to speak about their research at the STEM 4 Innovation conference coordinated by the Spark! team. The networking and communication practices that the teachers developed during their RET involvement helped to sustain their connection to the SECURE faculty and staff long after the summer experience concluded.
